general_info: Nafcillin, approved by the US FDA in 1970, is a semi-synthetic penicillinase-resistant Penicillin used in the treatment of staphylococcal infections caused by methicillin-susceptible strains of Staph. aureus (MSSA).
usage_and_dosing.adult_dose: Usual dose (bacteremia with or without endocarditis): 2 gm IV/IM q4h

renal_adjustment.crcl_or_egfr: No dosage adjustment for renal impairment

hepatic_adjustment.note: If concomitant renal and hepatic dysfunction, reduce dose by 50%.

adverse_effects: Like all beta-lactams, main problem is allergic rash.
Neutropenia occurs in over 10% of patients treated for more than 3 weeks. WBC can fall below 1000 cells/µL. Reversible if Nafcillin therapy is stopped.
Rare AEs: Coombs+ hemolytic anemia; thrombocytopenia, C. difficile colitis, hypokalemia.

pregnancy_risk.fda_risk_category: No evidence of toxicity in humans or animals
pregnancy_risk.use_during_lactation: No data, but adverse effects not expected. Monitor infant for GI toxicity.

preferred: Staphylococcus sp., coagulase-negative (Methicillin susceptible); S. hominis, S. capitis, others
